courses.name: Language & Literacy in the Primary-Junior Divisions
courses.desc:
This course will facilitate an understanding of reading, writing, oral communication and media literacy in the Primary and Junior divisions with a focus on exploring current thinking about language processes and the implications of these insights for instructional practice. 
This course is only available to students in the Bachelor of Education (BEd) degree program.

courses.name: Mathematics in the Primary-Junior Divisions
courses.desc:
Examines teaching and learning mathematics in the Primary and Junior divisions. Emphasis is placed on mathematical processes, cross-curricular and integrated learning, and differentiation in mathematics teaching and learning.
This course is only available to students in the Bachelor of Education (BEd) degree program.

courses.name: Science & Technology in the Primary-Junior DIvisions
courses.desc:
Examines developmental theories, epistemic assumptions and pedagogical practices in science and technology in the Primary/Junior divisions. Topics include: play, inquiry and problem solving, creativity and wonderment, curriculum analysis, concept development, science and technology within social and environmental contexts.
This course is only open to students in the Bachelor of Education (BEd) degree program.

courses.name: Social Studies & Culture in the Primary-Junior Divisions
courses.desc:
Examines the concept of cross-curricular learning in Social Studies in the Primary and Junior divisions. Students will explore themes central to teaching and learning history, geography, social life and culture.
This course is only available to students in the Bachelor of Education (BEd) degree program.

courses.name: Physical Education in the Primary-Junior Divisions
courses.desc:
Examines the design, delivery and fundamental principles of teaching health and physical education in the Primary/Junior divisions. Students will explore the development of physical and health literacy and the facilitation of authentic learning engagements through a comprehensive community/school health model.
This course is only available to students in the Bachelor of Education (BEd) degree program.
